utterances: Mm-hmm.
And Greenspan did bail somebody out - it was long-term capital -and he was given accolades as being a genius for having done that.
I think Bernanke should be accorded those same words.
Mr.

Shiller, do you think that Mr. Bernanke at the end of this week is saying, well, that's the end of that and it's just going to swing the other way, or is he saying, gee, this could be the beginning of something really bad?

Well, I can't read his mind, but I imagine that he is really worried because he has taken a number of steps, you know, they created a number of new institutions - this term auction facility - and then the terms securities lending facility, and then the prime dealers credit facility.
These are major steps.
Now, we're loaning to non-banks, to dealers in treasury securities.
So, he's expanding the scope of monetary policy.
I think he is worried that he is going to run out of ammunition.
Cutting the Fed funds rate, he doesn't have that much further to cut it, so he's looking for other tools and I give him credit for that.
He's thinking ahead that we might have a serious crisis and he's acting on it.
I just wonder if you, Mr. Shiller, have confidence in Ben Bernanke at the end of this really difficult week.
The stock market seems to be saying, he's okay.
Well, I admire Ben Bernanke and I think he's one of the best choices.
On the other hand, I don't think that he or Greenspan were very focused on human psychology.
And I think that they didn't see this.
Final word from Juli Niemann?
When you're looking at the stock market though, this is a short-term reaction to what the Fed's doing, but we still have further to go on this because the recession is here, earnings are coming down.
We have to batten down the hatches.
Juli Niemann is an analyst with the brokerage firm Smith, Moore in St. Louis.
Robert James Shiller teaches at Yale University's International Center for Finance.
He is the author of the forthcoming book ""Subprime Solution.
Thanks to both of you.
Thank you.
A pleasure.
After a parliamentary election in Greece today, the conservative ruling party of Prime Minister Costas Karamanlis will remain in power.
Exit polls indicate the New Democracy Party could have only a slim majority in parliament.
The election was held just weeks after devastating wildfires in Greece.
Sixty-five people died as the Greek government struggled to cope with those fires.
NPR's Sylvia Poggioli, covered that story for us and is back in Athens today for the election.
Sylvia, what effect did those fires and those deaths and the government's action or the lack of it have on the election, do you think?
Well, Prime Minister Costas Karamanlis had called the votes six months ahead of schedule because he was confident his conservative New Democracy Party would have a landslide victory.
But then the state's ineffective response to the fires raised the specter of a government defeat.
And Karamanlis went into damage control mode.
He immediately started issuing about $4,000 in compensation to each fire victim.
The opposition Socialist Party, which was haunted by its own corruption scandals during its long run in power in the past was unable to benefit from voter anger over the fires.
Both major parties seemed to have lost ground to the advantage of smaller, radical parties on the left and on the right.
And for the first time in three decades, an extreme right wing party called L.A.O.S., which means Popular Orthodox Rally, will enter parliament.
Another sign of voter protest is a low turnout, perhaps below 70 percent.
And this is in a country where voting is considered compulsory.
And what do you think the result today of the voting is going to mean for the ruling party?

The New Democracy Party will be able to form a government on its own but it's a majority - seems to be slim and it could have a tough time passing reforms that are required to bring Greece into line with its European Union partners.
Greece has to reduce its deficit, it's one of the highest in Europe, and reduce the large number of people living below the poverty line.
Prime Minister Karamanlis has ruled out a coalition with the ultra right wing nationalist L.A.O.S.
Party.
So there is a real danger of a hung parliament and political instability in the months to come.
Sylvia, finally, when you think about, or hear about Greek politics, there are names that go back for many decades - Papandreou, Karamanlis.
Is this election, in any way, a turning point for the dynastic quality in politics there?
That's it - Irish dramatist Sean...
O'Casey.

I mean, there's a lot of cost involved with advertising the festival, trying to get people in the seats and stuff, so I mean, if you win the festival, certainly, you do get paid, you know, sometimes ten thousand dollars, you know.
There is a cash prize, but to be in the festival, a lot of times you have to pay.
And when you're just starting out and you're working at a comedy club, is there a set fee?
Do you get paid depending on how many people come through the door?
How does that work?
You know, it all depend on, like, if you're passed at a comedy club, you know, some clubs in New York City, I am pass and I do get paid for spots now, which is amazing.
But sometimes you don't get paid.
Sometimes you're just happy to get up on stage and for them to, you know, allow you to perform that night.
You used the word ""pass."" What does that mean?
Well, there are certain comedy clubs and they get people to - you have to audition to be passed at the comedy club.
Oh, to get through, to get on stage.
Right.
To be able to say, I'm a regular at, you know, at this club, or whatever.
I see.
To be able to say that to other people.
I know for bands starting out, a lot of them play for free except where they get a percentage of the people who come through the door holding their pamphlets.
Is there anything like that in the comedy business?
Yes.
There's a lot of that, actually, because in New York City there's just so many comedians that there's stages where you actually have to pay to perform, to be able to get five minutes of stage time.
They take five dollars from you at the door.
Just like you're coming in to watch.
Right.
Yeah.
And then a lot of times they let the audience come in for free because it's a lot of amateurs, at an open mic for instance, and so if, you know, it's not guaranteed a good show.
You're just trying out new material so you pay five dollars, the audience gets in for free, they get drunk and you get up on stage and try out your material.
And four years in the business, you've obviously got some talent because you're a semi-finalist on ""Last Comic Standing."" And as I understand it, you still have a day job.
You work full time in a dentist's office.
Oh, I work part time in a dentist office, right.
OK, but that's how you pay the rent?
Right.
That's how I pay the rent, until I can make comedy my sole living.

Well, joining us now from his home in Los Angeles is, well, one of the best-known comics in the business, Richard Lewis, famous for comedy tours and of course, his appearances on HBO's ""Curb Your Enthusiasm."" And Richard, you've been in the business...
I could say it in one minute.
Go ahead.
First of all, it's a pleasure to be on your show.
Thank you.
And good luck with your - four years, what memories, man.
Is she still on the air?
Yes, she is.
Listen, you know, good luck with everything.
Thank you.
It's all about the craft, because 99 percent of the people we're going to be dealing with are unscrupulous pigs, so...
